[**2150-4-26**]
1. Exploratory laparotomy.
2. Proximal jejunum serosal tear repair.
3. Local exploration of neck wound, with suture
ligation of several bleeders.

History of Present Illness:
This unfortunate 30 year old male
had a history of a prior motor vehicle accident, leaving him
to be paraplegic. He was an unrestrained passenger in a high
speed motor vehicle crash that resulted in the death of the
driver and in this patient being ejected about fifty feet from
the car. He was found unresponsive by the EMS personnel, and
he was transferred to an outside hospital with labile
hemodynamics. A right chest tube was placed for a
pneumothorax found on initial x-ray. There was
some difficulty intubating the patient initially, with an
attempt at an open tracheostomy that was unsuccessful.
Eventually the patient was intubated endotracheally and
underwent
a head CT and a torso CT scan on the outside as well.

His head CT showed multiple petechial hemorrhages and severe
diffuse brain injury in both hemispheres. He had a large
right frontal contusion with diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage.
He was noted to have swollen ventricles, severe facial
fractures, and right frontal bone and frontal sinus
fractures. Initially his torso CT was read as negative, and
he was immediately transferred by [**Location (un) 7622**] to our
institution.

Past Medical History:
Paraplegic s/p MVC
h/o alcoholism
h/o cocaine abuse

Social History:
h/o legal problems
h/o alcoholism
h/o cocaine abuse

Family History:
N/A

Physical Exam:
abdominal injuries (xlap with general) frontal bone fracture,
intervent hemorage x4, intraparychimal bleed, pneumocephalus, R
lat orbital wall fx, ICP to 90's, free air in abdomen

multiple petechial hemorrhages and severe
diffuse brain injury in both hemispheres.  He had a large
right frontal contusion with diffuse subarachnoid hemorrhage.
He was noted to have swollen ventricles, severe facial
fractures, and right frontal bone and frontal sinus
fractures.

Brief Hospital Course:
This patient was transferred from an outside hospital by
[**Location (un) 7622**] to [**Hospital1 69**].  Upon
arrival, he was noted to be tachycardic,
with a pressure in the low hundreds.  The torso CT scan was
reviewed by our radiologists, and there was a question of
free air seen, previously missed.  Due to his hemodynamic
instability, it was decided to take him immediately to the
operating room for an exploratory laparotomy.  On [**2150-4-26**], this patient
was taken to the operating room of the [**Hospital1 827**].  The patient underwent an Exploratory
laparotomy, Proximal jejunum serosal tear repair, Local
exploration of  neck wound, with suture ligation of several
bleeders.  This was performed by the trauma team and the
neurosurgical team placed an ICP bolt monitor during the neck
exploration. The patient was then transferred back to the
intensive care unit following his operation.

The remainder of his course was very difficult and the patient
had been previously been placed on full code by his family.  The
plan was to keep his ICP down, continue ventilation, b/l chest
tubes remained in place.  ENT and opthamology were also
consulted. Due to the patient's complicated course and poor
prognosis the patient's wife decided to make the patient
DNR/DNI.  The organ bank was contact[**Name (NI) **] and the family, including
the wife and father remained present for support.  A morphine
drip was started for patient comfort. The patient expired
shortly after confirmed with a brain death exam.  The patient
expired on [**2150-4-27**] in the intensive care unit.
